titlestmt.author: Andrea Castillo and Nancy Lorimer

publicationstmt.p: The Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University. All rights reserved.

titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the Richard and Mildred Crooks Collection
titlepage.publisher:
Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound
Stanford University Libraries
Stanford, California
titlepage.p: #169; 2006 The Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University. All rights reserved.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Materials documenting virtually every stage of Crooks career.
did.langmaterial: Languages represented in the collection: English

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Listening appointments may require 24 hours notice. Contact the Archive Operations Manager.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Archive of Recorded Sound.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: RIchard and Mildred Crooks Collection, ARS-0004. Courtesy of the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biography / Administrative History
bioghist.p: Alexander Richard Crooks, tenor, was born in Trenton, N.J. on June 26, 1900. He toured widely, and sang with the Metropolitan Opera Company from 1933 to 1942. Crooks recorded extensively for the Victor record company, and was featured on several radio series from 1929 to 1945. He married his childhood friend Mildred Pine in 1921 and they had two children, Patricia and Richard, Jr. In retirement, the couple settled in Portola Valley. Richard Crooks died on September 30, 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Materials documenting virtually every stage of Crooks' career, starting with newspaper clippings and programs apparently kept by his mother from his appearances as a boy soprano in churches, at resort concerts and in vaudeville. Included are materials related to Crooks' high school classmate George Antheil. The collection contains photographs, programs, and other items for nearly every role Crooks undertook at the Metropolitan Opera and memorabilia from the numerous concert tours and the years broadcasting the Voice of Firestone radio program (1932-1945), as well as sheet music. Included are letters from colleagues and friends from throughout his career and into retirement. Finally, Crooks' own recording collection, with test pressings, privately recorded materials, and several air checks (with Bing Crosby) are included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 12 series. I. Correspondence. II. Documents. III. Programs. IV. Photographs. V. Scrapbooks. VI. Clippings. VII. Publications. VIII. Libretti. IX. Sheet music. X. Sound recordings. XI. Audio-visual materials. XII. Miscellany.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.
controlaccess.title: Voice of Firestone (Radio program)
controlaccess.subject: Tenors (Singers)
Opera.

Sung by Richard Crooks and Lawrence Tibbett with Trinity Choir, Mark Andrews, organist. Originally recorded May, 1929 (from Victor M-64?)

scopecontent.p: Side 1: Saint-Saëns, Camille, 1835-1921. Samson et Dalila. J'ai gravi la montagne -- Verdi, Giuseppe, 1813-1901. Traviata. De' miei bollenti spiriti -- Donizetti, Gaetano, 1797-1848. Lucia di Lammermoor. Selections. Cruda, funesta smania -- Pallor funesto -- Dalle stanze ove Lucia.Side 2: Verdi, Giuseppe, 1813-1901. Otello. Ora e per sempre addio -- Mascagni, Pietro, 1863-1945. Cavalleria rusticana. Voi lo sapete -- Strauss, Richard, 1864-1949. Salome. Finale -- Schubert, Franz, 1797-1828. Musensohn -- Wagner, Richard, 1813-1883. Ring des Nibelungen. Walküre. Ho-jo-to-ho!

did.unittitle: The Golden Age of Opera. Potpurri (6)1936-1948

scopecontent.p: Side 1: Puccini, Giacomo, 1858-1924. Tosca. E lucevan le stelle ; Recondita armonia -- Traubel and Carron. Man without a country: My dearest : My own ; My life -- Wagner, Richard, 1813-1883. Ring des Nibelungen. Walküre. Ho-jo-to-ho! -- Smetana, Bedrich, 1824-1884. Prodan#225; nevesta. Selection -- Verdi, Giuseppe, 1813-1901. Traviata. Libiamo ne lieti calici -- Hahn, Reynaldo, 1875-1947. Ciboulette. Ce n'#233;tait pas la même chose.Side 2: Pergolesi, Giovanni Battista, 1710-1736. Tre giorni son che Nina -- De Curtis, Ernesto, 1875-1937. Torna a Surriento -- Bellini, Vincenzo, 1801-1835. Norma. Casta diva -- Donizetti, Gaetano, 1797-1848. Fille du r#233;giment. Selection -- Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791. Don Giovanni. Selection -- Leoncavallo, Ruggiero, 1858-1919. Pagliacci. Vesti la giubba -- Thomas, Ambroise, 1811-1896. Mignon. Selection -- Flotow, Friedrich von, 1812-1883. Martha. Selection -- Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791. Zauberflöte. O Isis und Osiris (Aria) ; In diesen heil'gen Hallen
